title: "We won so why are you upset"
body:
Just got done with a like 44 minute game in the slums, and at the end the 9/6/11 udyr and the 6/3/13 cait asked me why I was trying to surrender and getting upset.


For those of you who are completely unaware of what league of legends is, let's go over it.

Kill towers. Kill Nexus.

If you manage to do those two things, you win every game. Nothing else really matters. If we're up 9 kills 20 minutes in, but have no objectives, and we win ANOTHER teamfight and don't get anymore objectives because you decide that wolf camp looks juicy, I'm going to understandably say "what the hell are you doing?"

If it's 36 minutes in, and our team hasn't collected a single objective on the map, despite winning multiple fights where our carries are alive after; I'm going to be upset.

It's not rocket science. It's not a "comeback" when you finally decide you want to shoot a tower. It's nothing more than you deciding you finally wanted to play League of Legends and not CoD. Your goal isn't to reach 250 farm, your goal isn't to get sated by 22 minutes (wtf slow?), your goal isn't even to be 500 short of your next item and farm it rq. No. Your goal is to take the opportunity to kill the towers, then kill the nexus.


In the slums, that's the #1 thing people don't do. Ever. Forget the tunnel vision, forget constantly trying to play like you're ahead when you're 0-5 in lane, none of that is uncarriable. It's the guy who's 11-0 and just afk farming a frozen bot lane while the rest of the team fights 4v5, wins, and then we get absolutely no objective out of it.

Don't be a CoD kiddie. Play League of Legends. Shoot a tower once in awhile, take a stroll to the dragon pit, breath in the fresh air of what teams actually do to win the game outside of trying to be a bad-ass-one-shot-king. You'll get those badass-one-shot-king games like once in a hundred games, you should want to win way more than that.

Your team Won.

Stop trying to be a Quitter.  Might have won faster if you weren't so busy trying to get your team to Quit.

I hate quitters.  So did John Wayne.

I don't think you get it. My team won because I did 19k more damage to champs than anyone else in game, you could've added the 2nd and 3rd place up on my team to get them to where I was.

We didn't win slower because I wasn't actively trying to win, we won slower because my team wasn't actively trying to win.


If I'm put in a situation where I'm either going to blow up at idiots in chat for dragging games out and potentially lose the game or I can just surrender and move on to a game where at least 1 other person gets that we're supposed to kill towers, then I'm going to take the second option. Every time.

At 36 minutes when the tower score is 0-8 and dragon score is 0-4 it's no longer on me to be the voice of reason and beg my team to do things that make sense. That was 30 minutes before; when I was actively pinging objectives and watching the whole map like a hawk to and issuing warnings for other lanes that probably aren't paying as much attention.


So, no, I'm not a "quitter". I'd rather not be banned for asking someone how retarded they are for taking wolves after an ace; I'd much rather just be put on a team where someone doesn't decide that's a good idea instead of taking the tower sitting right in front of us.

I get it completely.

You were in a game where the outcome wasn't settled, where you could still Win (as proven by you actually Winning).

And you wanted to Quit.

You are a Quitter that wasn't allowed to Quit, because the others were still holding out trying to Win.  Sure, they sucked.  Sure, they didn't know how to secure the Win.  But they were still out there, refusing to give up.

They all sucked, every single one of your Team Mates.  You were WAY better than any of them.

Yet still, you were the only Quitter.

If your decision or attempt is to leave a game where the Outcome isn't Settled... you are by definition a Quitter.

It's cool.  You choose to Quit to get to an easier game.  That's your right.  Your option.

Doesn't make you any less of a Quitter, though.

For you, you find it more Time Efficient (and likely more Stress Efficient) to simply Quit and move to the next game.  Cool.  That just means you Quit Economically.

Not sure why you'd be upset about it either, it's your choice.  You made the decision.  Your time and stress was worth more to you than finishing out the game, had only your team agreed.

But no way around it, no matter how you try to sugar coat it or defend it... you were still Quitting on your Team.

It's not a hard concept to comprehend.
I have no idea how being a quitter in a video game is a bad thing especially when you get paired up with mind eating shitters.

I didn't say it was bad, outside of the time spent trying to /ff, in which during that action you aren't engaged in trying to Win.

I'm merely calling a spade a spade.  He had every right to quit if he so felt justified, and he made his valid attempt.

He got out-voted, decided then to not AFK, and they Won.

But the fact is, he still tried and wanted to quit, which by definition makes him a quitter.  If quitting saves him time and stress, then cool.  It has a benefit for him.  That's his choice.

But now he seems to be defensive of his choice for some reason.

I never said he wasn't justified in his decision, just that at the end of the day he is in fact a quitter.

That's a very broad definition because that would make virtually every person on the planet and who ever lived a 'quitter' at something. We use words to compartmentalize ideas that are very narrow without overlap. As suggested by the google definition:

'Someone who gives up *easily*.'


'Easily' is still very relative, but it's better than 'someone who quits something ever.' Honestly you're fighting over words now.
